stem: A 30-year-old client with a history of hyperthyroidism is in the PACU following a subtotal thyroidectomy. She suddenly develops extreme muscle rigidity and a core temperature of 105.1°F. Based on the documentation in the Post-Surgical Hyperthermic Differential Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hyperthermic crisis in the recovery room.
Background: Received Succinylcholine and Isoflurane intraoperatively.
Assessment: Client’s jaw is locked (masseter spasm) and skin is mottled. Heart rate is 158.
Recommendation: Stabilization for Malignant Hyperthermia vs. Storm.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Dantrolene sodium immediately as prescribed
Initiate cooling protocols (Cold saline, Ice to axilla/groin)
Administer STAT IV Propranolol to treat the hyperthyroid component
Encourage the client to take deep breaths to lower the CO2

parameterOptions.text: End-Tidal CO2 (ETCO2) and Core Temperature trends
Muscle rigidity status and Serum CK/Potassium levels
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Malignant Hyperthermia (c2). While Thyroid Storm (c1) is a valid concern in this patient, the extreme End-Tidal CO2 (82 mmHg) and 'Lead-pipe' muscle rigidity (specifically lockjaw) are the hallmarks of MH, triggered by Succinylcholine or volatile gases. Priority #1 is the specific antidote, Dantrolene (a1), and Priority #2 is rapid cooling (a2). Key parameters include tracking the CO2 (the earliest sign) (p1) and monitoring for rhabdomyolysis/potassium spikes related to the rigidity (p2).
clinicalPearls: The earliest sign of MH is a sudden rise in End-Tidal CO2 (ETCO2), NOT the fever.
Dantrolene is the only muscle relaxant that treats the underlying calcium-release problem in MH.
Family history of anesthesia complications is the most important risk screening tool.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as a thyroid storm because the patient has Graves' disease.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the muscle tone. Thyroid storm causes tremors and agitation. MH causes 'Stone-like' rigidity and a locked jaw. Also, check the ETCO2; it will be much higher in MH.

mnemonic.title: M-H-D
mnemonic.expansion: M-Muscle rigidity. H-High CO2/Temp. D-Dantrolene is the drug.
